basics.name: Hyoyeon Lee
basics.label: Computer Science
basics.summary: Final Year BSc Computer Science Student in University of Bristol

work.name: Faculty of Engineering, University of Bristol
work.summary: Worked as a Faculty-Funded Research Assistant under the supervision of Dr. Christina David.
highlights: Developed automated software that verifies the correctness of generated proof harness functions of a given C program from LLMs using CBMC until valid results are obtained.

work.name: School of Computer Science, University of Bristol
work.summary: Supported students by leading problem classes and delivered over 200 hours of teaching.

work.name: School of Computer Science, University of Bristol
work.summary: Supported students by leading problem classes and delivered over 200 hours of teaching.

courses: Machine Learning, Image Processing and Computer Vision, Types and Lambda Calculus, Applied Data Science, Computer Graphics, Algorithms I/II

awards.title: Best Visual Award
awards.summary: Created hand-drawn assets and backgrounds, bringing an immersive atmosphere to life through illustrations and animation. Implemented core gameplay mechanics in C#, including interactive elements and scripted dynamic to player actions accordingly. Awarded “Best Visual Awards” funded by ‘MyWorld’ with prize of £100.

awards.title: Bristol Plus Awards
awards.summary: Earned the esteemed 'Bristol Plus Awards' from the University of Bristol for contributing 70 hours of work experience and participation, awarded to fewer than 5% of Bristol students in any given year. Held positions such as GDSC Marketing Director, Teaching Assistant, and UG School of Computer Science/International Students Course Rep. Developed essential communication, employability, and interpersonal skills through these roles and workshops.

publications.name: Zur Elektrody/namik bewegter Körper
publications.summary: It concerned an interpretation of the Michelson–Morley experiment and the properties of light and time. Special relativity incorporates the principle that the speed of light is the same for all inertial observers regardless of the state of motion of the source.

publications.name: Über einen die Erzeugung und Verwandlung des Lichtes betreffenden heuristischen Gesichtspunkt
publications.summary: In the second paper, he applied the quantum theory to light to explain the photoelectric effect. In particular, he used the idea of light quanta (photons) to explain experimental results, but stressed the importance of the experimental results. The importance of his work on the photoelectric effect earned him the Nobel Prize in Physics in 1921.

publications.name: Die Grundlage der allgemeinen Relativitätstheorie
publications.summary: The publication of the theory of general relativity made him internationally famous. He was professor of physics at the universities of Zurich (1909–1911) and Prague (1911–1912), before he returned to ETH Zurich (1912–1914).

projects.name: Language Evolution in Iterated Learning Models Using Variational Autoencoders and Image-Based Meanings
